												   X3AP is an amazing space themed sandbox. There's so much to do that it can be quite overwhelming. But is strangely addictive and can easily drain your life away with its immensely entertaining game play.   Now the vast majority of this review is going to be about what I really didn’t like about the game; however, over all I still love this game and find it extremely entertaining.   First and foremost are the missions for the main plots. If I didn’t spend the time to research what they were and what I needed to do to qualify for them I would have probably never known they existed at all or how to unlock them. While this is an open ended sandbox game I felt that it was too hard to unlock the main plot missions and several of them such as the missions that require you to capture ships are next to impossible without consulting Google to see how others managed to complete them.   Another gripe I have with missions is that they can be very buggy which is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if you haven’t saved recently. You may end up having to revert to a previous save game file (assuming you used multiple files to save for each play through which I HIGHLY recommend for this very reason) I had several of the main story line missions just halt their progress. As an example, one mission I was supposed to be escorting a convoy and the entire convoy got killed because my capital ship was too slow to keep up with them. But rather than failing me and allowing me to redo the mission it just kept telling me to escort the dead convoy that was there and continually spawned fighters to attack me. I wasn’t even able to abort the mission in the hopes of restarting it and ended up going back to a previous save file and losing hours of work.   On to the different types of starts, I believe they are falsely labeled as to their difficultly. Some of the starts that Egosoft has labeled as average or normal such as the "Anonymous  Argon" are next to impossible to do, You can’t really take most of the missions because you have no weapons, no life support, no money , and virtually no way to get forward momentum in the game at all. While others that such as the "Bankrupt assassin" start are labeled hard and it’s possible to have a hundred million in your bank within a few hours with this start. The point being that to the novice player who's just trying to jump into the game with little to no understanding of how it works it’s extremely easy to become discouraged and quit simply because you wanted to play the "Easy" or "Normal" start and you ended up with a start that causes even advanced players to say "Yeah ♥♥♥♥ this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; after 30 minutes.   Next is traveling. I'm a Avionics Technician and a helicopter pilot out here in the real world. I have worked in aviation for over 6 years and statistically speaking a real auto pilot fails around one time in a billion and even then most of the time it isn’t life threatening. Yet somehow the auto pilot in the game manages to kill me at least once an hour. Because of this little flaw traveling is extremely tedious and time consuming until you manage to get a jumpdrive and even then buying new ships is a pain. I'll use the Terrans as an example, the ships are sold in one sector, and the equipment such as jumpdrives are sold 10 sectors away where 5 of the sectors are full of capital ships trying to kill you so getting through there in a new ship without equipment can be challenging to say the very least.   My last big complaint is that this game is extremely complex which is a good thing, and at the same time a bad thing. Its good because it gives the player tons of options for fleet controls and commands but like all complex tasks it takes quite a bit of time to complete them. So when you get the game rolling and have a few hundred stations and ships it can get a bit time consuming micromanaging everything and in combat situations controlling fleets and issuing orders can be insanely hard especially since you can’t make custom macros (or at least I couldn't find out how using the vast resources available on Google) to do many of the ship specific actions like launching your marines for a boarding party. Something that needs to be extremely precise, requires you to go through 5 command and selection menus before they will get off your damn ship. All while you're in the middle of a battle. Where ideally all you would have to do is press a button or hells in real life just say the words "Get out."   Now despite all of the short comings have listed here and several others that I didn’t I believe X3AP is a truly beautiful game and it offers a type of play style and control that I haven’t seen in any other space game franchise. It has an immersive and rich universe that’s easy to get lost in and some of the most enjoyable space combat I have experienced in a game.    I give this game a 7 out of 10 it could easily have been a 9 out of 10 with some polishing by the game studio. It's a very fun game and I highly recommend it if you are looking for a space themed game. You should just have to expect to spend about 10 hours learning to master the controls.

												X3: Albion Prelude is a spacecraft game focusing on trading and fighting. Even through a main plot and some minor quest are available too in my humble opinion the main focus is the open world aspect. The player can focus on two aspects fighting, trading or a mix of both of course. Progression is done by buying, capturing or boarding spacecrafts of five races (or four plus one offspring to be more precise) and some minor fractions of every race. The X-series in general never reinvented the wheel, a lot of aspects are taken from other space games or movies. For example the trading follows the principal of Elite, the concepts of the gates like in the series Babylon 5 and fighting with fighters, carriers and destroyers was already seen in games like Wing Commander.X3 is the latest offspring of the classical X-series, starting with X: Beyond the Frontier. Albion Prelude itself is Add-on which adds additional ships, systems and possibilities to the 'main' game X3. While the successor X Rebirth does change a lot of aspects of the game, X3: AP is the crown of the older games. If you are familiar with some of the older titles and want to have more options, buy AP! It has more from anything.The strength of this games is definitely the economy aspect, especially building an empire with production, mining or trading. Not as complex as a business simulation game (lets say Capitalism) but deeper IMHO then Starlancer. The races have distinguishable designs, wares and strengths. Even through the attitudes of every race is a bit exaggerated. Another big plus: Every ship is flyable, some of them are hard to come by, but it is possible to obtain a little scout ship (called M5) or a big destroyer (called M2). Everything you can see, you could ride. The game also gives the player a lot of options how to play. Focusing of bounty hunting? No problem. More into a mining empire? Just go for a miner. Piracy? Yes of course. More into building a space station to produce stuff? Go for it. Additionally the game has a strong modding scene, which adds even more options if you want to.Of course there are also some weaknesses. The game is very slow. If you want fast action, better go for some other space games. You should be willing to invest 50-60 hours of game-play before your empire starts to kick off. Before you can acquire a full quipped carrier, you have to play weeks. Also the AI, especially the way finding, have some major issues. You should never fully trust your autopilot. It either does some bizarre manoeuvre or could fly you straight into a asteroid. Both 'big' issues are in there since the start of the first X. You should be willing to accept this, otherwise you will not having fun. This and some little things prevent the game to be the MUST HAVE title it could have been.Summery. You want a space sim with a big economy aspects. Your are not after a fast action heavy space-ship-stuff and you can live with some oddities, but want to be rewarded with variety of play choices. You want massive hours of playtime for your money? Go for this! Even through it has flaws I couldn't point to a better game in its category.

												These games are really good.  The X series is a slow burn of space exploration, dogfighting, trading, and slowly clawing your way up from an insignificant speck in a vast and uncaring universe. 												This is my favorite space sim game.  It has many strengths and many weaknesses.  I will start off with the weaknesses of the game to get them out of the way so I can focus on the fun parts of the game.This is a single player game.  There is no multiplayer, so if you were hoping to play this with others, this isn’t the game for you.  To many, this is actually a good thing.The graphics isn’t really up to par for 2013, but I don’t find them too objectionable.  There isn’t many similarly capable space sims on the market *yet*, so beggars can’t be choosers.There is a somewhat steep learning curve since there is so many aspects to the game, and the built in tutorial doesn’t really do enough explaining and is even fairly easy to skip over by accident.  To get the most from this game you probably will need to spend a lot of time researching how the game works by a combination of reading Egosoft forum postings, watching youtube videos (which there are some great ones), reading other guides online, and general trial and error accompanied with a lot of saving and loading.Probably the thing I hate most about this game is collision.  The autopilot is somewhat bad and will sometimes guide your ship into other ships or gates in space which will seriously damage or explode your ship.  If you have a fleet of ships in system with you it only gets worse.  I can’t believe they left it as is.  Basically every time you go through a gate, there is a chance the autopilot is going to collide with the gate and blow you up.  It gets worse the bigger the ship you’re in.Missions:The main storyline missions are fun and rewarding.  As rewards you are given things like  spaceships, space stations, and an entire private sectors.  These missions are somewhat easy, especially as compared to older incarnations of X3.  For example, you will have a much easier time completing the hub plot as compared to X3: Terran Conflict.  They have stripped out much of monotonous aspects of the storyline missions.  You still have to work for them so you are not left feeling like you didn’t earn them.The random side missions that you find everywhere are a mixed bag.  Some of them are impossible or nearly impossible to complete, with strange caveats, or strict time limits.  If you play for a long time you kind of learn which ones to skip and which ones are worth doing.  I feel like they could improve this so you don’t waste as much time.Trading:In this version, they added a Stock Market, which can be exploited to give you a quick infusions of starting money.  That’s all I ever used it for, as a network of trading ships seems to be more reliable and earn quicker.The trading system is one of the best things about this game.  There are lots of goods for sale and lots of buyers, so there is plenty of opportunities to make money. You can manually trade goods yourself and or set up huge fleets of automated traders so you can get a lot of passive income while you focus on other tasks.  This takes a bit to fully get working as you have to download a bonus addon pack and spend some time learning how to configure your ships to use them.  But once you have this going, you can have 50+ ships automatically finding the best trade runs and doing it on your behalf and sending you the profits.  All you have to do is replace them when they eventually get blown up.Building:You can build vast networks of your personally owned stations generating weapons and goods for use, or for selling.  Creating player owned stations is probably my favorite aspects of the game.  These can quickly give you a lot of money which you can further reinvest to expanding your holdings.Once you acquire the “Player Headquarters” from a storyline mission, you can reverse engineer other ships to acquire the blueprints so you can build your own.  You can also scrap other ships here which breaks them down into resources to build other ships from.  The one downside to the Player Headquarters is that it’s slow.  Combat:With multiple sizes and classifications of ships, weapons, and shields, combat can be extremely fun.  You have everything from your quick interceptor/scout types that move fast with low hitpoints and weak weapons, all the way up to nearly immobile capital ships with massive weaponry and that can act as carriers which allow you to transport and field a large number of smaller ships.You can cause pilots to bail out of their ship, which you can then claim as your own,  and also board their ship and take it over from within.  The boarding is very fun once you have capable enough marines and have the tactics down.Mods:There is a fairly easy to get into scripting interface with a largish modding community, and lot of existing mods you can download which can improve many aspects of the game, such as the above mentioned collision problem.

												   X3AP is an amazing space themed sandbox. There's so much to do that it can be quite overwhelming. But is strangely addictive and can easily drain your life away with its immensely entertaining game play.   Now the vast majority of this review is going to be about what I really didn’t like about the game; however, over all I still love this game and find it extremely entertaining.   First and foremost are the missions for the main plots. If I didn’t spend the time to research what they were and what I needed to do to qualify for them I would have probably never known they existed at all or how to unlock them. While this is an open ended sandbox game I felt that it was too hard to unlock the main plot missions and several of them such as the missions that require you to capture ships are next to impossible without consulting Google to see how others managed to complete them.   Another gripe I have with missions is that they can be very buggy which is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if you haven’t saved recently. You may end up having to revert to a previous save game file (assuming you used multiple files to save for each play through which I HIGHLY recommend for this very reason) I had several of the main story line missions just halt their progress. As an example, one mission I was supposed to be escorting a convoy and the entire convoy got killed because my capital ship was too slow to keep up with them. But rather than failing me and allowing me to redo the mission it just kept telling me to escort the dead convoy that was there and continually spawned fighters to attack me. I wasn’t even able to abort the mission in the hopes of restarting it and ended up going back to a previous save file and losing hours of work.   On to the different types of starts, I believe they are falsely labeled as to their difficultly. Some of the starts that Egosoft has labeled as average or normal such as the "Anonymous  Argon" are next to impossible to do, You can’t really take most of the missions because you have no weapons, no life support, no money , and virtually no way to get forward momentum in the game at all. While others that such as the "Bankrupt assassin" start are labeled hard and it’s possible to have a hundred million in your bank within a few hours with this start. The point being that to the novice player who's just trying to jump into the game with little to no understanding of how it works it’s extremely easy to become discouraged and quit simply because you wanted to play the "Easy" or "Normal" start and you ended up with a start that causes even advanced players to say "Yeah ♥♥♥♥ this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; after 30 minutes.   Next is traveling. I'm a Avionics Technician and a helicopter pilot out here in the real world. I have worked in aviation for over 6 years and statistically speaking a real auto pilot fails around one time in a billion and even then most of the time it isn’t life threatening. Yet somehow the auto pilot in the game manages to kill me at least once an hour. Because of this little flaw traveling is extremely tedious and time consuming until you manage to get a jumpdrive and even then buying new ships is a pain. I'll use the Terrans as an example, the ships are sold in one sector, and the equipment such as jumpdrives are sold 10 sectors away where 5 of the sectors are full of capital ships trying to kill you so getting through there in a new ship without equipment can be challenging to say the very least.   My last big complaint is that this game is extremely complex which is a good thing, and at the same time a bad thing. Its good because it gives the player tons of options for fleet controls and commands but like all complex tasks it takes quite a bit of time to complete them. So when you get the game rolling and have a few hundred stations and ships it can get a bit time consuming micromanaging everything and in combat situations controlling fleets and issuing orders can be insanely hard especially since you can’t make custom macros (or at least I couldn't find out how using the vast resources available on Google) to do many of the ship specific actions like launching your marines for a boarding party. Something that needs to be extremely precise, requires you to go through 5 command and selection menus before they will get off your damn ship. All while you're in the middle of a battle. Where ideally all you would have to do is press a button or hells in real life just say the words "Get out."   Now despite all of the short comings have listed here and several others that I didn’t I believe X3AP is a truly beautiful game and it offers a type of play style and control that I haven’t seen in any other space game franchise. It has an immersive and rich universe that’s easy to get lost in and some of the most enjoyable space combat I have experienced in a game.    I give this game a 7 out of 10 it could easily have been a 9 out of 10 with some polishing by the game studio. It's a very fun game and I highly recommend it if you are looking for a space themed game. You should just have to expect to spend about 10 hours learning to master the controls.
